newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: TENNIS-CHESNOKOV SALVAGES PRIDE FOR RUSSIA.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-CHESNOKOV SALVAGES PRIDE FOR RUSSIA.

text.p: Andrei Chesnokov salvaged a measure of pride for a losing Russian side when he upset world number eight Wayne Ferreira of South Africa in their Davis Cup reverse singles match on Sunday.
In the hottest temperatures of the World Group first round tie, the 31-year-old broke a lacklustre Ferreira twice in the deciding third set to win 6-2 6-7 (7-9) 6-2 in one hour and 47 minutes.
That gave South Africa a 3-1 victory overall in the tie to line up a probable second round clash away to Sweden in April.
The scheduled second reverse singles match between South Africa's Marcos Ondruska and Russia's Andrei Cherkasov was abandoned after the Russian played more than 30 games in the morning's doubles.

In that earlier match, the South African doubles pair of Ellis Ferreira and Grant Stafford outclassed the Russian combination of Andrei Olhovsky and Cherkasov 6-2 3-6 6-0 6-2 to give the home side an unassailable 3-0 lead in the tie.

"It's a great feeling to have won this tie. We were expected to win but the first three matches were all tough. This victory is very satisfying," South African non-playing team captain Danie Visser said afterwards.
"At the end of the day, the surface here in Durban was a little slow and the guys had to work very hard - but they managed to come through in the key matches."

On-court temperatures reached 42 degrees celsius as the South Africans swept through the first set 6-2 in only half an hour, with the left-handed Ferreira winning several points on crunching forehand drives.
The Russians fought back with three breaks of serve to take the second set 6-3 as Olhovsky, ranked 23rd in world doubles, began to mix powerful ground strokes with some intelligently-placed lobs.
"They threw up a lot of lobs in that set and, for quite a while, the sun was right in our faces in the middle of the court," Ferreira said. "But, once the sun moved, it wasn't that bad."

Despite intense humidity, the South Africans then upped a few gears to breeze through the next two sets 6-0 6-2 in only 45 minutes. They broke the Russians three times in the third set and twice in the fourth to seal overall victory for their country n the tie.
